node.title: There is error when run  ./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
node.bodyText:
When  I run ./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
Cannot use fblaslapack without Fortran, make sure you do NOT have --with-fc=0

Thank you.

Cannot use fblaslapack without Fortran, make sure you do NOT have --with-fc=0

There was an error. Exiting...

Hello
What compilers are you using? It says earlier in the log I think.
You can also query:
echo $CC $CXX $FC

then for good measure please report their version too
Guillaume
@liuyong201811 what does this return?
mpicc mpicxx mpif90

and mpicc --version.
I m expecting clang 10.0, but just checking

ok checked the configure log and it confirms clang 10 is being used. There s still some references to the installed gcc version I find suspicious but maybe that's normal, like this one Selected GCC installation: /usr/lib/gcc/aarch64-redhat-linux/4.8.5
You are getting a bunch of fortran and BLAS errors at the end. Have you tried the solution they suggest in the script?

mpicc --version
Bisheng Compiler 1.3.3.b023 clang version 10.0.1 (clang-e31092d4f8cd flang-3c92ea4b404f)
Target: aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /opt/compiler/bisheng-compiler-1.3.3-aarch64-linux/bin
They did not give the method to solution a bunch of fortran and BLAS errors at the end. Or they give but I do not know to do it.thank you

open the update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh script in a text editor and change --download-fblaslapack=0 to --download-fblaslapack=1
see below.

You can just do:
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh --download-fblaslapack=1

Arguments are passed to petsc configure.

I try it but it did work.
then the wrong changed into

     UNABLE to CONFIGURE with GIVEN OPTIONS    (see configure.log for details):


Error configuring STRUMPACK with cmake

The wrong changed into
UNABLE to CONFIGURE with GIVEN OPTIONS    (see configure.log for details):
Could not find a functional BLAS. Run with --with-blas-lib= to indicate the library containing BLAS.
Or --download-fblaslapack=1 to have one automatically downloaded and installed
Where can I set --with-blas-lib or --download-fblaslapack=1, thank you!

you can change those options inside the update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh script.
This is kind of an advanced use case though. There is likely another issue

configure.log
this is the configure.log, can you help me to see what is the issue,thank you.

Is your gcc version 4.8?
Minimum required is 5.1
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/manual_installation_gcc.html

I use the clang to compile the program .
[root@DC5-02-010 moose]# clang -v
Bisheng Compiler 1.3.3.b023 clang version 10.0.1 (clang-e31092d4f8cd flang-3c92ea4b404f)
Target: aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu

Target: aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /opt/compiler/bisheng-compiler-1.3.3-aarch64-linux/bin
Which of our instruction pages are you using to setup your build environment?
We want to install Moose in  ARM  machine and clang flang clang++, Can you give some advice to us, thank you!

It is a straight forward process building on a Linux ARM machine (@dschwen used a Raspberry Pi3 as I recall, and I was on a Beaglebone, and one other successful attempt on a raspberry 4), but that was while using gcc, g++ and gfortran. Not the LLVM toolchain.
Flang is a fairly new compiler. I don't think anyone our team will have much if any experience. Indeed, when I search the internet for BLAS and Flang, I don't get promising hits. I am genuinely curious if this works. It would be nice to have an entirely LLVM solution.

I installed moose in wsl for download and had the same problem when building PETSc.This is a problem I have not encountered before installing moose, I do not know how to solve it.

In the new Discussion please also include the actual error you are receiving, along with the above diagnostics output.
Thanks!

node.title: ADStressDivergenceRZTensors
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to model an axisymmetric problem in cylindrical coordinates via ADStressDivergenceRZTensors.
So, it seems that the x direction represents the radial direction and y is z direction of a cylinder. How can I access to hoop stress, sigma_tt, in this case?

Hello
You should be able to pass generate_output = 'hoop_stress' to the tensor mechanics master action to generate this output
Guillaume

node.title: Number of new grains at each time step
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am doing recrystallization simulation using MOOSE. Next, I would like to know how many new grains are generated at each time step. Is it possible to get it as an output data in MOOSE?
I would appreciate if you could manage time to reply.
Best regards,
Zahid

node.title: Imposing a BC that includes a time derivative of the main variable
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE community,
Is it possible to have a boundary condition that accounts for the time derivative of the main variable? I want to impose the following boundary condition (third equation in the following picture and the main variable is also phi). In the 2D problem, this condition would be on the bottom boundary which is a horizontal line. Is there any similar condition related to this specific problem in the framework?

Thanks,
Ali

Hello
Yes this should be doable. Use the routines from the coupleable interface (coupledDot) to get the contribution to the residual right.
I think to get it completely right you ll want to also contribute to the "time" matrix and vectors. See the TimeKernel.C for how this is done (changing the tags).
Guillaume

node.title: Converge problem of ImplicitEuler time integrator
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
After learning the Troubleshooting Failed Solves, Convergence criteria and Setting Appropriate Convergence Criteria, I have a question about the convergence in MOOSE.


Can the default time integrator 'ImplicitEuler ' in MOOSE can solve any kernels/PDE?


Whether the Courant–Friedrichs–Lewy condition still working for implicit (matrix) solvers?
How could we use it in MOOSE?


Based on my limited experience, either an increased permeability, or increased injected mass rate at point source or decreased mesh size would require a smaller maximum dt compared to the initial case. How could we understand this?
For example, at the first 50 steps, the hydor-thermal problems in porous_flow can converge by meeting the relative or absolute
nonlinear to 1e-8 in the increased permeability case of 3.5e-13 m2. However, it cannot converge at the Time Step 51, time = 547378, dt = 109476 s. The only reason for this non-convergence is the increased permeability from 1e-13 m2 to 3.5e-13 m2.
Time Step 50, time = 280256, dt = 56051.9
0 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.053181e-05
1 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m3.028068e-08
2 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m3.111575e-09
Solve Converged!
Time Step 51, time = 350321, dt = 70064.9
0 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.037218e-02
1 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.035678e-02
2 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.023458e-02
3 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.017689e-02
4 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.004332e-02
5 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.001222e-02
6 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.001222e-02
7 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.001222e-02
8 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.001222e-02
9 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.001222e-02
10 Nonlinear |R| =  [32m1.001222e-02
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_MAX_IT iterations 10
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Thanks for your help.
B.

Hello
Yes as long as there are no higher order (second, third etc) time derivatives in the PDE.
There can be some restrictions on the timestep but because it s implicit usually not.
For your convergence problem, did you try to let the timestepper cut the timestep and try again?

The CFL conditions depend on your PDE and on your time integration scheme. They can be derived from a von Neumann stability analysis of your equation iirc
For porous flow it s an advection - diffusion like problem right?
I think the stability of the time integration scheme is not the only thing at play here. There is also the convergence of your Newton / pjfnk nonlinear solve. With a large timestep your initial guess is further from the solution. Unsing a predictor can help

Thanks for your reply.

I am not sure I understand this sentence or not.


There can be some restrictions on the timestep but because it s  implicit usually not.

Do you mean that 'If it is implicit scheme, for 1st order time derivative, there is no restrictions on the timestep.
For higher order time derivative, there are restrictions on the timestep.'. Is it right?


What is the reason for the unconvergence in the above example since there should be no restriction on the time step beacause I use the implicit first order time derivative?


In addition, with implicit first order time derivative, I found that convergence is dependent on the grid size and flow velocity. For example, high flow velocity results in a small dt.  I am using Newton nonlinear solve and timestepper cutting the timestep.  After 3 steps, the dt increased close to 70064.9, it get cut again.
But from my understanding, any dt should work since I use implicit first order time derivative, which is unconditional stable.

I did not exactly mean that.
I meant that higher order derivatives are not implemented for 1st order Implicit Euler in MOOSE. I think only the Centered time integrator and Newmark Beta have them implemented.


If it is implicit scheme, for 1st order time derivative, there is no restrictions on the timestep

It depends on the time integration scheme, there are more than one implicit scheme.
There are aoways restrictions on the timestep, because you need a certain level of accuracy and because the nonlinear problem solver cannot find a solution if the intiial guess is too far from the solution.
@cpgr can you please comment on CFL conditions for porous flow?
I dont think it's a classic advective problem right? Because of Darcy's law

node.title: node numbers need shift in LinearNodalConstraint and Output by -1? Abaqus mesh related?
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose-Forum,
I like to use Abaqus-meshes via the 'FileMeshGenerator'. However, we noticed when testing the 'LinearNodalConstraint' for a simple problem, that using the node labels for parameters primary and secondary_node_ids cannot be used as input in the mesh file.
We understand that abaqus meshes should have both node and element labels consecutively numbered starting from label 1 (actually starting with node label 0 is not valid any more, which makes sense).
Also, the flag  allow_renumbering=false was set.
Still the node numbers that one needs to specify within LinearNodalConstraint need to be shifted by -1 to make the result be correct. If using the node labels that are input, the result is wrong.
Below is a screenshot of both versions.

Also, attached are the files to reconstruct this problem.
Is this intended to shift nodes labels by -1, or is it a bug?
The user might end up with very unintended results if the mesh in more complex involving many more nodes.

Hello
The offset in the ids is expected. We have the same problem with paraview sometimes.
allow_renumbering=false is for parallel / repartitioning renumbering, not the offset.
If this is really impacting your workflow I would recommend either:

adding a parameter to the FileMG to number as you expect
creating a RenumberNode/ElementIDMG mesh generator object to perform this operation

Guillaume

Hi GiudGiud, thanks for your reply.
Do we understand correctly, that a Moose mesh internally always labels nodes from 0 to nNodes-1, but elements from 1 to nElems? Is this always the case, no matter which labels are defined in the input file that is fed to FileMeshGenerator? And will this convention remain or is this likely to be changed in some near future?
So, if read from an Abaqus *.inp mesh with consecutively numbered nodes and elements starting both from 1, all the nodes are relabelled internally by an offset of -1, but elementLabels remain unchanged - so any nodeLabel that is specified later in the inputfile (eg., to define constraints, outputs, etc) need to include this nodeNumber-shift?
Thanks a lot for clarifying,
Arnd

in libMesh/libmesh#3640 we made sure that we went from the 1-based numbering of Abaqus for both nodes and elements to 0-based, so you are half-correct. We translate the Abaqus numbering by -1 for both elements and nodes

node.title: NCG Convergence
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am doing a NCG simulation of an isolated cylinder that is filled with unsaturated soil and has a fixed temperature at the center and at the wall. I encountered some issues with the massfraction being >1, so I switched to KT stabilization.
In my case, convergence with adaptive iteration is pretty bad, at first hovering back and forth between cutback and dt 200-300s, finally leading to dt < 1 s and failure.
Maybe someone could have a look at my input and tell me what I am missing, or is the physical situation just too complex (I dont think so)? model.zip
An example of the terminal output until first failure is pasted below.
What tends to happen is that the liquid phase (initial saturation of 32%) flows to the bottom of the mesh (image below), which logically would makes sense for a very permeable medium, however it happens within the first few 100's of seconds and for the modelled medium with a permeability of 1e-12 this just does not seem right.
When setting the permeability to lower values, e.g. 1e-20, the model converges very well.

node.title: Customised elements
node.bodyText: I am trying to derive the week form of three coupled equilibrium equations for a 3-layer plate. I can do the FE formulation using additional DoFs, which requires a new type of element. How can I do this? Thanks.

Hello
Making custom elements is more of a libmesh change than something we can do in MOOSE.
What type of new element do you need?
Guillaume

Hi,
Thank you for your reply. I am modelling a three-layer sandwich structure. The elements can be Lagrange ones, but I the DoFs are a combination of displacements and rotations of the three layers. For instance, the first DoF is the average of deflections of the top and bottom layers, the second DoF is the average of their rotations. I am not sure how to address this.
As a side question, I have used the principle of virtual work and obtained the virtual internal and external works. I am also struggling to take this form to the standard kernel form that MOOSE requires.
Thank you very much for your help.
kind regards,
Zia

Could you use multiple variables to host each dof?
We for example can have X and Y components of the displacement in two variables, and then there are two DOFs at each node (one for X, one for Y)

first DoF = average of the first components of deformation for layers 1 and 3
second DoF = average of the second components of deformation for layers 1 and 3
third Dof = difference of the first components of deformation for layers 1 and 3
...

Should you make these averages variables that are only defined in layer 2 then?
These dofs are supposed to live on layer 2 right?
Basically, the three layers are modelled as one layer with all the DoFs on it. I can send you my paper if it helps.

I think you could a one layer mesh with the 9 variables defined in a as in the figure above.
We can solve problems with multiple variables.
If some of the variables are simple averages , you can use auxiliary variables to take them out of the nonlinear solver

The virtual work formulation is based on these averages so the DoFs must be these variables. Is there any examples available for something like this? Also do you know how to reformulate the virtual work expression into weak form suitable for MOOSE? Thanks.

I dont know about the virtual work. @gambka @cbolisetti  ?
the DoFs must be these variables seems like you should have a variable field for each of them.
Thank you very much for answering my questions. Do I need to do anything specific for a "variable field"?

A variable in moose is a field that is defined over part or all of the mesh.
There are variables that have DoFS on nodes (for example Lagrange) and others that have dofs at various locations on elements (for example monomial or Bernstein)
Guillaume

node.title: Mapping AuxVariable that is Monomial to a Lagrangian one....
node.bodyText: I've been playing with a problem where I have a populated monomial variable, I want to populate a material object with the contents of that variable. What is the right way to do this? I basically am I trying to use the gravity kernel from tensor mechanics, which requires density as a material object, my material density is currently variable contained within a monomial auxvariable.

Hello
The ParsedMaterial can convert a variable into a material property.
If you want to use AD (and density depends on a nonlinear variable), rewriting your density as a material property is the way forward instead of forwarding from an auxiliary variable
Guillaume

So, what im doing is trying to use topology optimisation on 'real' geometry where some bits can be modified and some can't. So for example, I have two blocks, the red (not being optimised) and white being optimised. With the toy problems i've fixed the ends, and I'm pulling down (gravity nodal kernel) on the bottom.

However, I want to apply it to a real problem, and thus I'm building complexity by setting the density to be fixed in the red, and variable on the basis of the SIMP method. I would like to use the tensor mechanics gravity kernel to determine the gravitational forces.
The examples found in the optimisation folder of the installation, have  AuxVariables like
  [Emin]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
    initial_condition = ${Emin}
    block = 'inner'
  []
  [power]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
    initial_condition = ${power}
    block = 'inner'      
  []
  [E0]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
    initial_condition = ${E0}
    block = 'inner'     
  []
  [Dc]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
    initial_condition = -1.0
    block = 'inner'
  []
  [mat_den]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []

So I was using the density here, and setting it block with;
[ICs]
  [block1]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = mat_den
    value = ${vol_frac}
    block = 'inner'
  []
  [block2]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = mat_den
    value = 1.0
    block = 'outer'
  []
[]

I was then filling the nodal AuxVariable with the density, and then using
[Materials]
  [density]
    type = GenericFunctionMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = get_density
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [get_density]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'alpha'
    symbol_names = 'alpha'
    symbol_values = mat_den_nodal
  []
[]

This segfaults however;
*** ERROR ***
Unsupported order: 0
Stack frames: 18
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: libMesh::MacroFunctions::report_error(char const*, int, char const*, char const*, std::ostream&)
2: /home/adavis/opt/moose/moose/scripts/../libmesh/installed/lib/libmesh_opt.so.0(+0x787861) [0x7f1feb387861]
3: libMesh::DofMap::reinit(libMesh::MeshBase&)
4: libMesh::DofMap::distribute_dofs(libMesh::MeshBase&)
5: libMesh::System::init_data()
6: libMesh::System::init()
7: libMesh::EquationSystems::init()
8: FEProblemBase::init()
9: Action::timedAct()
10: ActionWarehouse::executeActionsWithAction(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
11: ActionWarehouse::executeAllActions()
12: MooseApp::runInputFile()
13: MooseApp::run()
14: main
15: /lib64/libc.so.6(+0x27550) [0x7f1fe284a550]
16: __libc_start_main
17: /home/adavis/opt/moose/moose/modules/combined/combined-opt() [0x4044f5]
[0] ../src/fe/fe_lagrange.C, line 777, compiled Nov  7 2023 at 15:03:29

So instead, you're saying I should set density via the material object, and instead use an AuxKernel to populate the AuxVariable, so MaterialRealAux to populate the AuxVariable. That would give the ability to set whats needed, but at the end of the timestep I would need to update that material object, would that be a PostProcessor?

what is mat_den_nodal ?
[Functions]
  [get_density]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'alpha'
    symbol_names = 'alpha'
    symbol_values = mat_den_nodal
  []
[]

functions cant depend on variables.
The seg fault is concerning. We definitely would want your input or a reduced version of it to fix this.
You can use the MaterialRealAux  to populate the auxvariable indeed. The variable is only needed for output right? The material property is actually what is being used in the optimization ?

No, the material property isn't being used in the optimisation, I've modified https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/combined/examples/optimization/2d_mbb.i to use the Gravity kernel, but the the density, mat_den is a monomial auxvariable since the element is either density greater than 0 (on) and 0 (off), that density is updated by a postprocessor on the basis of the SIMP compliance. I was trying to update to use the kernel, such that this is reflect in variable mass rather than a fixed mass in that example.
@lynnmunday
@somu15

@maxnezdyur Has examples that limit the optimization to a specific block while not optimizing the other blocks for a fixed load.  Is the load you are applying a function of the density so as the optimization changes the density field, it also changes the load?  I don't know that I've seen an example of SIMP for a problem like that.  @maxnezdyur will know, he implemented all of this.

node.title: Does SUPG in INS momentum kernel automatically cover custom source (external force) terms?
node.bodyText: As stated, I defined some new source terms in INS momentum equation. I also noticed the SUPG option in INS momentum kernel. I wonder if custom source terms are automatically covered by this SUPG option; otherwise, I should implement SUPG to new source terms by myself.

Hello
No if you want SUPG to be consistent with the new source term, you should modify the computation of the momentum equation strong residual in the INSADTauMaterial (see materials/INSADTauMaterial.h). You can see a lot of the terms there, for example Boussinesq or a coupled force strong residual.
Guillaume
Hi, thanks for clarifying. However, I use the INSMomentumTractionFormRZ, which seems not an AD kernel. Should I keep modifying residual in INSADTauMaterial?
If your body force is described by a function, then you can use the forcing_func parameter in your INSMomentumTractionFormRZ block. This will be included consistently in the SUPG stabilization
Thanks for your support. However, the force term I need requires gradient calculation and variable coupling. Is function method capable of these?

Functions can only depend on space, time, and postprocessors.
So it cannot.
I guess I need to modify the corresponding kernels you and @lindsayad mentioned before. Thanks!
I finally managed to fix the issue. The simplest way I found is to modify the body force expressions in INSBase.C.
